title: Integration with Operations Orchestration
content:
Introduction

Service Management provides an Operations Orchestration (OO) integration that allows you to automate tasks or integrate with other products. The integration uses the On-Premises Bridge to connect SMAX to an Operations Orchestration installation. This document describes how to configure the OO integration with Service Management and provides an example of how to use SMAX with OO.

This chapter will include instructions to:

  • Create the OPB Integration User
  • Install the OPB Agent
  • Configure SSL for OPB
  • Create the Endpoint
  • Configure an OO Endpoint
  • Use SMAX with OO
  • Troubleshoot the integration 

Create the OPB Integration User

A suite admin user needs to create an Integration User within the Suite Administration before it can be used within the Tenant. To do this, access the Suite Administration URL. The URL resembles the following example:

https://smademovm07.swinfra.net/BO  

Once logged in go to the Users section.

Click New to add an Integration user.

Enter all relevant user details, paying key attention to the Role value, where the account must be set to Integration user and not Account user.  

Once all details are entered click on Save.

Once the Integration user has been created, the next step is to activate the account. Click on the created account to access the details.

Click Activate and then Save.

The system will send an activation email to the email address provided in the details of the account. The link in this activation email will allow you to set the password for this Integration account. This password will be required later when entering the details into the OPB.

Next, assign the user to a Tenant. Click on the Tenant tab on the top of the screen.

Choose the relevant tenant that the Integration user will access.

From here, click on Users so the integration user can be linked to this tenant.

Click on Attach and then choose your Integration user.

Click Attach and then Save.

Now within the Tenant this user will need to be synced. In order to do this, log in with a Tenant Admin user. From the Main Menu, click on Administration and then People.

Click on Sync if the new Integration User is not listed.

Once the Integration user appears within the tenant, assign the appropriate rights.

Open the Integration user and scroll down to the section System use definitions. At present only the Self-Service Portal User will exist. Type 'OPB ' and you should see the role OPB Remote Agent. Click on this to add the role. Do the same for Tenant Admin Role if required. In the following example, either Tenant Admin or IT User can be used. If you want to limit the permissions that the Integration user can use, do not assign the Tenant Admin role.

Once all permissions have been added click Save.

The Integration user is now set up.

Install the OPB Agent

Login to the Service Management tenant with a Tenant Admin User.  

Go to Agent Interface.

From the main menu, navigate to the Integration area under Administration and Utilities.

From the Agent screen, click on Download agent to download a copy of the Agent install file locally on your computer.

Copy the Agent install file across to the server which will run the On-Premises Bridge Software.

Go through the installation process which is described in this link (specifically the section on Installing OPB):

Go to the following location:

C:\ProgramData\MicroFocus\On-Premise Bridge Agent\product\util\opb

Double-click on credential_mng_ui.

This will open the Credentials Manager in order to create Endpoint credentials within Service Management.

Once it opens, click New.

Select the type of Endpoint being created (in this case 'Operations Orchestration Domain'). Click OK.

Enter a name for the Credentials being created. Provide the username used by Service Management to connect to OO (which will connect to HCM) along with the password. Once all details are completed, click Save.

Configure SSL for OPB

Before the OPB and OO can communicate, SSL certificates need to be added to the Java keystores. Without this, errors will be reported when trying to test the connection between the Service Management Endpoint and OO.

Export OO Server Certificate

On the OO Server, go to the OO installation location. If you installed OO into the default folder paths it should be something like:

C:\Program Files\Micro Focus\Operations Orchestration or C:\Program Files\Hewlett-Packard\HP Operations Orchestration

In <OO-Installation-Folder>\central\var\security there are two certificate stores, the key one is:

key.store

From the <OO-Installation-Folder>, go to <OO installation dir>\java\bin

Run the following command to see what alias exists in the key.store:

keytool -list -keystore “C:\Program Files\Micro Focus\Operations Orchestration\central\var\security\key.store”

To export the certificate run the following command:

keytool -export -alias tomcat -keystore "c:\Program Files\Micro Focus\Operations Orchestration\central\var\security\key.store" -file " c:\Program Files\Micro Focus\Operations Orchestration\central\var\security \OOserver.cert"

Copy the OOserver.cert file from the C:\ Program Files\Micro Focus\Operations Orchestration\ central\var\security folder to the relevant folder on the OPB server.

For OPB, place in the following location:

C:\ProgramData\MicroFocus\On-Premise Bridge Agent\product\util\3rd-party\jre\lib\security

Import SSL Certificates into OPB

This certificate file must be loaded into the OPB server for it to talk to the OO Server by SSL over port 8443. This is done by running the following command:

keytool.exe -import -keystore "C:\ProgramData\MicroFocus\On-Premise Bridge Agent\product\util\3rd-party\jre\lib\security\cacerts" -alias OOServer -file "C:\ProgramData\MicroFocus\On-Premise Bridge Agent\product\util\3rd-party\jre\lib\security\OOserver.cert"

When prompted for the password enter 'changeit'

Once the SSL certificates have been uploaded to the OPB, restart the On-Premises Bridge Agent Service. 

Create the Endpoint

Log into the Service Portal with an Admin User.

From the Main menu, click on Agent Interface.

Once the Dashboard has opened, go to the Large Menu and Select Administration -> Utilities -> Integration.

Note: This assumes all previous steps to install OPB Agent have already been completed on an appropriate server.

Click on Endpoints.

Within the Endpoints screen click on Add. Here a new Windows will appear asking for Endpoint type, Endpoint name and Running on agent. Fill in the details like so and click Add.

This has now created an Endpoint for OO on the OPB.

Configure the OO Endpoint

Once the OPB is configured and the OO certificate uploaded into the Java Keystores, one final configuration is required. The Endpoint that was created earlier needs to be configured. Go to the Endpoint and click on Configure. Enter the OO URL details as shown below.

Click on Test connection. If everything is configured correctly then you should see the below response.

Click Save to keep the configuration settings. The OPB will then connect to OO and run a Sync Task. This will allow SMAX to see all the OO flows that are configured within OO. When creating an Automated Task within Service Management it will be able to search OO for the correct flow which will be required.

Using SMAX with OO

In this example, we’ll set up a simple OO flow and then create an Offering in Service Management to allow a user to request a Password Reset. This will then trigger the OO flow that has been created and show the time that can be saved using automation within the ITOM tools. The scenario will also capture if the request is unsuccessful and generate an incident within Service Management.

To create this scenario, these instructions assume you have access to the Postgres Database server that is used for Service Management. If not, then it might be worth creating a PostgreSQL DB to follow this example through.

Create OO Flow

Within OO Studio make sure the following Content Packs have been installed:

  • OO Service Management Automation – X Content 3.2.0 to deploy this you also need the below CPs
  • CSA integrations content pack 4.70 or higher
  • OO 10-base-cp-1.16.0

These can be downloaded from the ITOM MarketPlace website: 

https://marketplace.microfocus.com/itom/category/operations-orchestration

For this example, the flow will only use 3 steps and have error and success options. The flow will look like below.

In order to create this flow, create a new project and give it a name for example DB Flow. Right Click on Library and create a new folder called postGres. Right Click on the postGres folder and then click New Flow. Give the flow a name: PG Password Reset.

A blank workspace will appear.

The first object that needs adding to the flow is SQL Command as this will be the starting point for the flow. In the Dependencies pane in the bottom left of Studio, expand out the Base 1.16.0 Content pack as shown below.


Then drag the SQL Command onto the canvas.

Next is to find the SMAX Create Incident and Get Token objects.


Now drag Get SSO Token and Create Incident objects on to the canvas.

So far, the canvas should look a bit like this:


Now we need to join the objects together to create the flow. To do this, two more objects need to be added to the flow. From the top bar of the Canvas area click on the following icon.

Drag both the green tick and the red cross onto the canvas.

The screen should now look like this:


Now the flow can be fully joined up. The key here is to understand what you expect to happen as this flow runs through. The flow starts at the SQL command. If the command can be actioned correctly then a success outcome is returned. If the SQL Command fails, then an incident needs to be created within Service Management. For OO to create an incident in Service Management, first it must log in and acquire SSO Token as the user is then authorized to log in. Then using the account details provided via the SMAX integration user, it will then create an incident in Service Management based upon the fact that the SQL Command failed.

The flow will now look like this:

Now the flow has been designed, the next part required is all the inputs to allow the flow to work.

At the bottom of the screen click on Properties

Here all the required inputs that need to be supplied from SMAX need to be entered.

The Table below shows what must be entered.

To use a system account this needs to be configured first. In the Projects pane expand Configuration and select System Accounts. Right-click and select New System Account.

Enter the name that best describes this account.

Enter the details of the account and click Save.

Now for the rows above highlighted in Yellow the newly created Service Account can be used.

The row above highlighted in Green is to show that the variable <userPassword> is passed into the SQL command to update the password based upon what the user wants to set the password to.

Back at the Inspector pane for SQL Command, click on the Results tab.

Then Click on the Plus button and leave the default values as shown below:

The SQL Command is now fully configured.

The most important row is the properties row to create the incident. There are key bits of information required from SMAX to do this. Most notably what is the user ID that is creating the incident, what service is affected by this incident and where should this incident be assigned to. All these values need the IDs providing, so you’ll need to check within your own SMAX environment in order to provide these details.

For the Results tab, enter the details below:

Name

Sensitive Data

From

Assign To

Assignment Action

Filters

IncidentID

ResultField: entityId

Flow Variable

OVERWRITE

No Filters

For the outputs from OO to be sent to SMAX the Resolved Success object needs updating so that it can handle a couple of the inputs and provide output to Service Management.

These two input fields need configuring as well as two output fields like so:

Name

Sensitive Data

Required

From

Otherwise

entityID

IncidentID

completionResult

No Filters

Flow Output Field

OVERWRITE

No Filters

Save the flow as it’s now complete.

Create Content Pack

From the Projects Pane, right-click on the DB Flow folder and select Create Content Pack.

Select the location where you want the content pack to be saved and check the version number is what you want to use and click Next

Check all the Dependencies are correct as these will need to have been loaded into OO central before this flow can be loaded.

Click Create CP.

Now the Content Pack has been successfully created.

Next is to import the Content Pack into OO central.

Log in to OO Central

From the main screen, click on Content Management and then click on Content Packs.


Click on the plus icon to import your new content pack.

The Deploy New Content window will appear. Click on the plus icon to navigate to where you saved your content pack.

Select the appropriate CP and click Open.

The CP will be checked to make sure it can be imported. Content and any dependencies will be checked at this stage. If there are any errors, they would need correcting before the CP can be deployed. If everything is fine. Click on Deploy.


The CP has now successfully been deployed into OO Central.

If you check the Content Packs page in OO Central, you will see the version of the CP and also the time it was uploaded.

The final aspect to set up for the flow to work is the Configuration Items.


The key fields that need updating are below:

Name

Deployed Value

Central Value

DB Account

postgres

postgres

SMAX Account

cmdbopb

cmdbopb

Now all the OO work is complete.

Create SMAX Offering

Prerequisite work

For the OO Flow to create an incident the Integration account needs to be given appropriate rights to be allowed to create an incident.

From the Agent view click on the Main Menu and go to Administration then People.

Select the Integration user that is required for the OPB to use and then under the System use definitions assign the appropriate rights to allow Incident creation. In this example Tenant Admin role has been assigned but if you need to limit the permissions assigned IT User could be used.

Now create the Offering

From the Agent view within Service Management go to Service Catalogue. In here either use an existing Category or create a new one. For this scenario, we’ll use the Business Application category with a Business Application of eExpense which has already been defined. It is here that an Offering of Password Reset will be created.

Within Offerings Click New. Then enter in the relevant details about the Offering like shown below.


Next is to define the User Options. These are important as this is what will be passed from SMAX to OO for the flow to use to reset the password. Information passed back from OO will be stored here also.


The following table breaks down exactly what fields need creating with the appropriate values.

Name

Display name

Field type

Field size

Required

Visibility

DBServerName_c

DB Server Name

String

MEDIUM

Yes

User

DBType_c

DB Type

String

MEDIUM

Yes

User

DB Port

String

MEDIUM

Yes

User

Database

String

MEDIUM

Yes

User

New Password

String

MEDIUM

Yes

User

String

MEDIUM

Yes

User

SMAXLoginUrl_c

SMAX Login Url

String

MEDIUM

Agent

Smax Url

String

MEDIUM

String

Agent

Next is to create the Task Plan. It’s this that allows SMAX to take the values from the above user options and send them across to the OO Workflow to Reset the Password.

Within Task Plan go to the First line Support and click on the Pencil icon at the bottom of Start.

Select Automated Task from the menu of options. A new screen will appear. Give the Task a name.

Under Business Rule click on + Set rule. A new window will appear for what type of rule you’ll want to set. Scroll down to the Integration Actions and Select Execute Operations Orchestration (OO) flow. Then click on OK.

Now the Task will give you several selections to make to configure the Business rule.

Enter the details as requested for your environment. First, you’ll be asked for the OO Endpoint. Then the flow name that you want to run. Here a new screen will appear allowing you to search OO for the relevant flow. In the search box, type PG and click on search.


The PG Password Reset flow that was created earlier within OO should be returned. On the right-hand side, the mandatory fields are shown which should match up to the User Options that were created earlier. Click OK to add this flow.

The next part that must be entered are the flow parameters. This is how SMAX knows what fields to map across to OO.

Rather than just type in the relevant values of what should be supplied, functions need to be used as some data needs supplying by the end user. There is other information which will not be supplied by the end user but will be set by the agent as a default value. Make sure you click on the fx button, it is then highlighted blue and then entity the function.

The Table below shows the values entered above for each field

Field Name

Value

DBServerName

${entity.UserOptions.DBServerName_c}

DBType

${entity.UserOptions.DBType_c}

DBPort

${entity.UserOptions.DBPort_c}

Database

${entity.UserOptions.Database_c}

userPassword

${entity.UserOptions.NewPassword_c}

SMAXLoginURL

${entity.UserOptions.SMAXLoginUrl_c}

smaxIncidentModelID

${entity.UserOptions.SmaxIncidentModelID_c}

smaxTenantID

${entity.UserOptions.SmaxTenantID_c}

Once all values have been entered, click OK.

Next, enter the Output fields using Add user Option.

Field Name

Value

SmaxIncidentID_c

Incident

OOcompletionResult_c

completionResult

Then Click OK to finish setting up the Automated Task.

It should look something like this:


Now that the Service Request has been created if a user enters values into the request but is unable to get their password reset the OO flow will try to create an Incident. To do this an Incident Model needs to be created within Service Management. Once this Model has been created the ModelID will then be set as a Default Value in the newly created Offering that was just created. Before we can continue to enter the Default Values for the Service Request we must first create the Incident Model.

Please note, for the OO output to be entered into SMAX fields a rule needs to be added to allow both User Options SmaxIncidentID_c and OOcompletionResult_c. This needs to be set within the Rendering Forms for Request in the Rules.

When the user is entering their new password, a check needs to be done that the passwords entered into the two password fields are the same value. This check needs to be done before the values entered can be passed to the OO Flow. This requires creating a Before Change Rule like shown below:

Set Rule type

Validate expression

If expression

${entity.UserOptions.NewPassword_c != entity.UserOptions.NewPasswordConfirmed_c}

Validate

${substring(entity.UserOptions.NewPassword_c, 0) == (entity.UserOptions.NewPasswordConfirmed_c)}

Display

The password entered does not match. Please re-enter your password!!

Incident Model

In Agent view click on the Main Menu and go to Incident. Then click on Models.

Click on New, then enter the relevant information that will help support deal with the Incident.

Click on Default Values and supply the relevant details for the Incident.

Click Save to create this Incident Model.

Next, click on Active to activate the model so OO now can use this Incident Model. Then click Save.

The incident model is now all set up, and you can return to the Offering you were configuring earlier. Just before leaving the Incident Model, make a note of the ID number of the model like 11847. This will be required for the default value in the Offering.

Service Request

Open the Password Reset offering, then click on Default Values.

User Option

Value

DB Server Name

<DB Server Name>

DB Type

<DB Type> e.g. PostgreSQL

DB Port

<DB Port> e.g. 5432

Database

<database> e.g. postgres

SMAX Login Url

<SMAX LOGIN URL> e.g https://FQDN_servername/auth/authentication-endpoint/authenticate/login

Smax Url

<SMAX URL> e.g. https://FQDN_servername

Smax Incident Model ID

<incident_Model_ID> e.g. 11847

Smax Tenenat ID

<SMAX Tenant ID> e.g. 829249256

Enter the appropriate values for your own environment. Please pay particular attention to SMAX user options as they need to match your own system.

Once all values are entered, click on Save.

Additional Tasks if Required

Now that the Password reset can be run automatically and either a successful result will be reported or an incident created. It is possible to use these outcomes to move the request along or link it to the incident that was generated. The following steps will show how this can be done.

Within the Password Reset offering, go to Rules.

Then in the After Change rule, create a new “If…Then” rule as shown below:

Set Rule type

Set Multiple fields

If expression

${entity.UserOptions.OOcompletionResult_c == 'Command completed successfully'}

CompletionCode

Fulfilled offline

Solution

Automated password reset completed

Set Rule type

Create relationship

If expression

${entity.SmaxIncidentID_c != null}

Relationship type

Incident caused by request

From record

${entity.SmaxIncidentID_c}

To record

${entity.Id}

Another rule that could be added is to inform the Requester by email that their password has now been reset. To do this, you could create a new Notification template or use an existing one.

To create one, go to Studio and then select Request.

Under Notification templates, click Add.

In the blank form, give the Notification a name and display name along with a subject line for the email.

Here is a table showing what can be entered as a Notification for the eExpense Application:

Name

PasswordResetNotification

Display Name

Notification of eExpense Temporary Password

Enabled

Yes

Subject

IMPORTANT - Temporary eExpense information for ${:entity.id}

Email Body

Hi ${:current_recipient.FirstName},

Your eExpense User Password for your Request ${:entity.Id} has now been updated based upon what you entered. You should now be able to access the eExpense Application

Thanks,

eExpense Application Management Team

Click Save to add this new Notification Template.

Go back to the Offering for Password Reset and then go to Rules. Now add a new After Change Rule so you can send a Notification to user that their Password has been reset.

Set Rule type

Send Notification

If expression

${entity.UserOptions.OOcompletionResult_c == 'Command completed successfully'}

Send notification

${entity.RequestedByPerson.Email}

Using

Notification of eExpense Temporary Password

Parameters

None

Run through the Password Reset Scenario

A user of the eExpenseDB can no longer access the database and needs to get their password reset.

Log in to SMAX with the user who would like to reset their password for the eExpenseDB system.

From the main portal page, click on Business Applications.

Click on Request Support for the Password reset offering for eExpense.

Fill in the form describing the problem and then click on Submit. The key values have already been populated based on what was entered for the Default Values within the Offering.


If the Password fields do not match, you’ll see the below notification until you correct the password fields:


This will also stop the user from being able to submit their new password till the two password boxes match each other.

After submitting the request, you should see the following screen to say a request has successfully been created.

Once the request has been completed, you should receive a Notification by email that your request has been completed. Now the user can access the eExpense Application with their new Password.

Now using the Agent view you can check how this request is getting on:

Click on Service Request.

From here you should see the new request that has just been generated.

Click on the request ID number to see the details of the request

If the additional steps have been carried out when configuring the Password Reset Offering then you will also notice the Request has been resolved and is waiting on the user to accept the solution provided.

The User can now Accept or Reject the solution that has been provided within the Service Portal.

Run through the same scenario – This time to show Incident Creation

Go to the same Password Reset offering within the Service Portal. This time change the default value for the DBPort from 5432 to say 3452 for example. All other values can be left the same or can be altered but it’s just to prove that the connection can’t be made using the settings provided and hence the Password Reset Task should fail.

Change the DB Port value and click on Submit.

Like before, a new Request will be created.

Go to the agent view the see the newly created Request.

Here are the details of the new request:

If you click on Task Plan, you will see the Automated Task completed successfully.


If you go to Incident Management, you’ll see a new incident has been created.

This successfully shows the OO flow created an incident due to the fact the details entered into the Service Request weren’t correct, so it was unable to connect to the DB. So, an incident has been raised by the cmdbopb user.

Again if the additional steps were undertaken what you’ll see is that the Incident is now linked to the request.


The SmaxIncidentID contains the created incident number and the OO Completion Result also gives some error information.

If you click on Related Records, you’ll see the Incident that is linked to the Request.

Troubleshooting

When troubleshooting the Integration between Service Management and OO there are several places to look.

The first place is within Service Management portal specifically looking at the Integration to check that no errors are being reported either with the Agent or on the actual OO Endpoint. If there are errors being shown here, it’s possible there is a problem with the OPB. In which case log on to the OPB Server and check the following log locations:

<OPB Install location>\On-Premise Bridge Agent\product\log\OperationOrchestrationDomain-1.0

In here check the following logs which should help to show if there is a communication problem from the OPB to OO:

  • OperationOrchestrationDomain-1.0.log.0
  • error.log
  • output.log

If the integration was successful but there are problems when trying to run an OO flow through SMAX the following log files which are stored in /var/vols/itom/itsma/global-volume/logs/xservices/platform/ look for the latest platform pod and then go to the maas folder. Inside you should look for the following logs:

  • Maas_error.log
  • Maas_workflow.log
  • Maas_oo_integration.log
  • Maas_unhandled_exceptions.log

Sometimes when using OO there may be a problem showing output from an OO flow within a User Option created in Service Management. If this problem occurs follow this procedure:

The rule of Property AITOOResultMessage is disabled is created by below request rule

"Disable all fields on the request tracking page in the Self-Service portal"

Follow below steps to add allow rule.

  1. Click Rendering form and click “Add a rule to run before request record rules”
  2. Choose Restrict/allow editing of fields in pop window and click ok button.
  3. Choose “Allow” in field “Restrict/allow”
  4. Click “all fields/ specific fields(optional)” and click Specific fields
  5. Click Add item and choose <Field Name>
  6. Select <Field Name> from dropdown and click ok and save button

If the integration still doesn’t work, contact the Service Management Support team and create a ticket. Be sure that all the OPB logs and configuration files are included.
